Summary Juan-Pablo is an experienced operator, investor, electrical engineer, and medical technology enthusiast. He is focused on bioelectronics, the next generation of nueromodulating medical devices. As a Partner at Action Potential Ventures (GSK's bioelectronics venture fund), Juan-Pablo invests in the companies and technologies that enable the future of targeted and adaptive bioelectronic devices.  
 
Additionally, Juan-Pablo is passionate about the future of mobile health technology that can deliver measurable impact to behavior change, health outcomes, and health economics (both by consumer and clinical standards). He is a believer that design and context drive engagement, that data must provide users a perpetual benefit, and that experiences must be pleasurable and habit forming to be adopted and remain relevant in a health context. Experience Software Engineer Stanford University May 2006  –  January 2012  (5 years 9 months) Developed molecular dynamics software to run on ATI (now AMD) and NVIDIA graphics processing units (GPUs) 
Supported and maintained the GPU version of Folding@Home, Senior Software Engineer Stanford University January 2006  –  January 2012  (6 years 1 month) Developed molecular dynamics software to run on ATI (now AMD) and NVIDIA graphics processing units (GPUs); the programs ran more than two orders of magnitude faster than CPU-based molecular dynamics programs. Software versions were available for Linux, Windows and Mac OSs. An extensive, automated testing framework for the programs was implemented 
Supported and maintained the GPU version of Folding@Home, a distributed computing application for folding proteins that runs worldwide on more than 70,000 GPUs  
Modified ISIM, a Grand Canonical Monte Carlo method for modeling electrolyte solutions of biomolecules, to allow for the graphical display of the results Principal Scientist Bristol-Myers Squibb January 2000  –  January 2006  (6 years 1 month) Developed processing pipeline and analysis software for proteomics data; a key element of the pipeline ran on a Linux cluster

Summary Plant Engineer at Stanford University's Central Energy Facility.  
 
Specialties include engineering support for safe, reliable operation and maintenance of gas turbines, steam turbines, heat recovery steam generators, electrical systems, and plant support equipment including water treatment, hydraulics, pneumatics, and HVAC. Summary My name is Ahmed AlSum, currently I'm a web archiving engineer at Stanford University Library. I'm responsible of the techncial activitiies of the Web Archiving initiative at Stanford University. I've Phd in computer sciece from Old Dominion University, specialized in web archiving. My research interests are information retrieval and web sciences in the web archiving environment. Before that I was a staff software engineer in Cairo technology development center, IBM Egypt. My experience is a mix from academic experience in computer science and professional experience in IT industry. 
 
The complete resume is available on this link:
